root.text:
Yeah, I should elaborate. Well-written documentation can be _great_ for collaboration. But well-written documentation can be _really_ hard to do, _even_ when the incentives are perfectly aligned (very rare even in open source; the world is complex). So lately I try to at least talk about the thing right in front of the thing rather than on some other page all by itself. That way at least if I screw up how I describe the thing, at least the reader has a chance at trying to cross-triangulate what I mean by looking at and running the thing itself.

But you're a Smalltalk guy. I suspect I'm preaching to the choir :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Interesting. Are there other ways than documentation that foster collaboration? Something less tiresome to maintain.

elements.text: Interesting. Are there other ways than documentation that foster collaboration? Something less tiresome to maintain.

text: Documentation does not have to be tiresome to maintain :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Documentation does not have to be tiresome to maintain

text: What I find interesting is telling a story about and with the system I am building. To do that I am forced to build the story in the system. This often leads to visualizations that describe internal aspects, and this leads to live documentation.

elements.text: What I find interesting is telling a story about and with the system I am building. To do that I am forced to build the story in the system. This often leads to visualizations that describe internal aspects, and this leads to live documentation.

text: I think writing documentation would be really fun if we had the right tools to do good storytelling. That's why I'm excited about efforts toward literate programming.

elements.text: I think writing documentation would be really fun if we had the right tools to do good storytelling. That's why I'm excited about efforts toward literate programming.

text: I think literate programming is interesting, too. But, we should not limit storytelling to words. Live and visual interactions are too powerful to leave out :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I think literate programming is interesting, too. But, we should not limit storytelling to words. Live and visual interactions are too powerful to leave out

text:
It seems obvious that the person who knows most about the system needs to document it. However, it turns out _good_ documentation often comes from other people, who had to understand the system from scratch long after it has been designed.

It’s hard to look at our own creations with a Beginner’s Mind again, but that’s really helpful, if not essential, to write good documentation.

And I’m not sure if writing documentation itself can be more fun — I’d like to think so. For sure though, there are people who like writing documentation. So it’s great if you have a chance to collaborate with those.

text: I do think that writing documentation can be fun if you have the right development experience for it

text: Since about 15 years I am practicing demo-driven development. This means that I drive my development form the point of view of the demo that I will give with and about it. This forces me to build the story into the system, including the visuals.

elements.text: Since about 15 years I am practicing demo-driven development. This means that I drive my development form the point of view of the demo that I will give with and about it. This forces me to build the story into the system, including the visuals.

text: And here I am referring to any details about my system. I think everything about my system should be explainable to a newcomer in minutes

elements.text: And here I am referring to any details about my system. I think everything about my system should be explainable to a newcomer in minutes

text:
It seems like large amount of documentation could be generated if we had proper programming environments.
Version incompatabilities, examples of usage, changes in API -- all of this can be generated.

What else is left? Stories, grand narratives? Use cases?

text: Thanks for the link to your comment. Very interesting :+1::skin-tone-3:

elements.text: Thanks for the link to your comment. Very interesting

text: There's the question of content (what should be written, what aspects covered). But there's also the problem of the representation medium - most documentation today is off to the side, completely disconnected from the artifacts it is talking about. This is a fundamentally fractured model. You not only have out of date stuff, but constantly jump back and forth. Instead of a clear distinction between 'docs' and 'code', ideally there would be a hypermedium with various views at different levels of detail: high level views (system design, narratives) all the way to low level views (code) - all of them interconnected and traversible.

elements.text: There's the question of content (what should be written, what aspects covered). But there's also the problem of the representation medium - most documentation today is off to the side, completely disconnected from the artifacts it is talking about. This is a fundamentally fractured model. You not only have out of date stuff, but constantly jump back and forth. Instead of a clear distinction between 'docs' and 'code', ideally there would be a hypermedium with various views at different levels of detail: high level views (system design, narratives) all the way to low level views (code) - all of them interconnected and traversible.

text:
That's an interesting discussion! I'd be neat if more people would collaborate on documentation, and as <@U5STGTB3J> pointed out, novices to a project are especially important as collaborators.
I wonder if more people would edit documentation if it wasn't owned by the project's owner. Think about having wikipedia-like editing right within your documentation. Especially if I'm new to a project, I'm always afraid to screw up other people's documentation by writing something stupid. I wonder if knowing that the next regular guy who reads my changes could easily improve or correct them would lower the bar to start collaborating.
Another option could be to include comments into each documentation page. People are used to providing feedback if they can, so they would probably point out a lot of issues that could then be used by maintainers to improve documentation.
Using current tools (IRC, github issues / PRs) all of this is possible already, but I think that making it easier and integrating it better into the documentation itself could make a huge difference.

Using current tools (IRC, github issues / PRs) all of this is possible already, but I think that making it easier and integrating it better into the documentation itself could make a huge difference.

text: GToolkit is doing going in this direction, it seems. E.g. you can have markdown like docs within which you embed live results of relevant queries on the code repository.

elements.text: GToolkit is doing going in this direction, it seems. E.g. you can have markdown like docs within which you embed live results of relevant queries on the code repository.

text: I agree that code and documentation should be as close together as possible. When talking about different views, *projectional editors* come to mind. The data structure they use internally is more like an AST and therefore more expressive than the "source text" commonly used today. You could add a "comment" attribute to each node type (module, class, even parts of an expression) or introduce additional node types only suited for documentation (tables, graphs, ...).

text: In general, PL designers seem to not think about program comprehensibility beyond code syntax and allowing you to insert a couple of characters here and there as part of a comment. I wonder how a programming system that focuses on being understandable by humans would look like. Rich documentation, visible connections / dependencies between components, abstract overview projections, ...

Rich documentation, visible connections / dependencies between components, abstract overview projections, ...

text: The 'syntax' is important only because the def facto medium is directly edited plain text files. To get all the good things you have to give that up, which unfortunately leaves you in a bubble.

elements.text: The 'syntax' is important only because the def facto medium is directly edited plain text files. To get all the good things you have to give that up, which unfortunately leaves you in a bubble.

text: yeah, moving away from text you lose a ton of nice properties.  I’m thinking searchability, easy generation / transformation, copy/paste.

elements.text: yeah, moving away from text you lose a ton of nice properties.  I’m thinking searchability, easy generation / transformation, copy/paste.

text: All of those things get better, no? It's just your text oriented operating systems and tooling don't work for you anymore.

text: haha, for sure. I don’t know specifically what you’re thinking of, I’ve just read other kinda of proposals for new program _authoring_ environments that don’t take into account program _comprehension_. Which I get concerned about.

text: TBH, I'm not bringing solutions, only problems. But one creeping realization I have is that fixing the problem might mean first changing some of the underlying assumptions and entrenched realities.

elements.text: TBH, I'm not bringing solutions, only problems. But one creeping realization I have is that fixing the problem might mean first changing some of the underlying assumptions and entrenched realities.

text:
'Comprehension' is key terminology here. Most people focus on 'readability' in the small rather than the sorts of global activities programmers need to do that look a lot more like reading comprehension.

I tend to think text is a perfectly fine way to do comprehension. We just need to do a better job (in some fairly straight-forward, actionable ways) within the context of existing text-based systems. Maybe going beyond text will also be helpful, but that seems an open question. For now, text is an assumption I'm content to retain. <@U8A5MS6R1> and I have argued this before :slightly_smiling_face:

text: pulling out that distinction between readability and comprehension is useful

text: We also can embed various views of examples. Examples have assertions, like tests, but they also return the object. Combined with the fact that objects can have different facets and with the fact that we can embed these artifacts in a document, it becomes a highly effective mechanism. We have a simple example framework that replaces the testing framework and we now practice example-driven development.

elements.text: We also can embed various views of examples. Examples have assertions, like tests, but they also return the object. Combined with the fact that objects can have different facets and with the fact that we can embed these artifacts in a document, it becomes a highly effective mechanism. We have a simple example framework that replaces the testing framework and we now practice example-driven development.

text: Great point. I'm careful now to use the phrase 'plain text files'.  Things like spreadsheets, Subtext and <http://infra-structure.org|infra-structure.org> are excluded by text oriented systems like Git. You still have text in these systems, mainly at the boundary with the reader (not necessarily as a large blob though, but organized within a different structure). If you have projectional interfaces, much of the content could be text. But why version and store large blobs of text when you really want history and different projections of the richer interconnected structures that are being represented? That's my thinking anyway.

text: Ah, that's a good distinction that you've had to remind me of a few times now. Very subtle and seems to easily fall off my head.

elements.text: Ah, that's a good distinction that you've had to remind me of a few times now. Very subtle and seems to easily fall off my head.

text:
Just realized that documentation usually describes higher level of abstraction about code. It describers into what layers program is split, or what functionality several applications should provide.

There must be a tool that would parse plain English statements with links to your code, transform it into some constraints, and then apply these constraints while developing. This will connect documentation and code more tightly, reduce chance of being obsolete.

Say you're writing in documentation that: "The whole application is split into three layers: A, B, C. A and C layers never communicate. A consists of ComponentA1, ComponentA2. Components in C layers are all located in 'c_layer' directory". A tool gonna parse it and produce rules:

```
layer('A', 'ComponentA1').
layer('A', 'ComponentA2').

read_components_in_dir('C', "c_layer").

io_allowed(Component1, Component2) :-
  layer('A', Component1), layer('C', Component2), false;
io_allowed(Component1, Component2) :-
  layer('A', Component2), layer('C', Component1), false;
io_allowed(Component1, Component2).
```

I'm not sure I got the Prolog code right, but you get the idea.

Thus it will throw a warning if it notices that code break constraint described in documentation.

This will motivate programmers describe higher level assumptions about code in documentation, because it constraints it and provides some kind of safety. Just like static typing or assertion does.

text:
Actually it reminds Gherkin somewhat: <https://docs.cucumber.io/gherkin/reference/>

To make this kind of constraints really work, it will require code and deployment identifiers to be located in single namespace. This way it would be possible to reason about anything in documentation, describe any type of constraints on application or service behavior,

That's why I look at IPFS with hope.

text: Parsing natural language to produce accurate queries is a hard problem. But, you do not need natural language for that. For example, <http://moosetechnology.org|moosetechnology.org> offers an extensive mechanism for writing queries like this. In fact, I believe this is the only way we can steer agile architecture.

elements.text: Parsing natural language to produce accurate queries is a hard problem. But, you do not need natural language for that. For example,
moosetechnology.org
offers an extensive mechanism for writing queries like this. In fact, I believe this is the only way we can steer agile architecture.

text:
Well, I still want to keep it as documentation first. Make it undestandable for humans first.

I'm fine with manual assistance of translating plain text statement into formula.

elements.text:
Well, I still want to keep it as documentation first. Make it undestandable for humans first.

text: The problem with this is that if you need to maintain it manually, it will get obsolete.

elements.text: The problem with this is that if you need to maintain it manually, it will get obsolete.

text: but, queries do not have to be unapproachable. A query could look like this: `componentA shouldNotUse: componentB`.

elements.text: but, queries do not have to be unapproachable. A query could look like this:
componentA shouldNotUse: componentB

text: Also, translating queries to natural language should be an easier problem than the other way around.

elements.text: Also, translating queries to natural language should be an easier problem than the other way around.

text: yeah

elements.text: yeah
